abstract: pmc Discov Nano Discov Nano 4402 discovernano Discover Nano 2731-9229 Springer PMC12474781 PMC12474781.1 12474781 12474781 41004033 10.1186/s11671-025-04360-1 4360 1 Review Carrier-free self-assembled nanomedicines of active ingredients from pomegranate peel: an overview Wang Manman 1 2 Zheng Dandan 2 3 4 Zhang Yulian 1 2 Cao Xueting 1 2 Wang Luo 1 2 Wang Jinglong jlwang8121@163.com 1 2 3 1 https://ror.org/0523y5c19 grid.464402.0 0000 0000 9459 9325 College of Pharmacy, Shandong University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, 2 https://ror.org/05x21tp94 grid.460162.7 0000 0004 1790 6685 School of Food Science and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Zaozhuang University, 3 4 https://ror.org/05x21tp94 grid.460162.7 0000 0004 1790 6685 College of Life Science, Zaozhuang University, 26 9 2025 12 2025 20 1 478452 170 9 7 2025 19 9 2025 26 09 2025 28 09 2025 28 09 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This study systematically reviewed the construction strategies of pomegranate peel carrier-free self-assembled nanomedicines and their performance in practical applications, aiming to provide theoretical support and technical path for the modernization of traditional Chinese medicine and the development of new drugs. Pomegranate peel is rich in polyphenols (such as ellagic acid and gallic acid), triterpenoids (such as ursolic acid and oleanolic acid), flavonoids (such as quercetin and baicalein) and other active ingredients. These components can be self-assembled to form nanostructures without exogenous carriers through intermolecular synergy, including hydrogen bond network, π-π stacking and hydrophobic interaction. This technology not only effectively improves the water solubility, bioavailability and stability of the active ingredients of traditional Chinese medicine, but also significantly enhances pharmacological activities including anti-tumor, anti-bacterial, anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidation etc. Compared with the traditional nanocarrier system, this method adopts the design concept of ‘active ingredient is carrier’, showing significant advantages in avoiding potential toxicity and improving drug loading efficiency, while retaining the structural integrity and synergistic effect of natural components. The study further pointed out that in the future, the self-assembly mechanism should be further explored, its application in precision medicine and individualized treatment should be optimized, and preclinical and clinical studies should be promoted to verify its safety and effectiveness. Combined with modern pharmaceutical engineering technology, promoting the large-scale production and industrialization of such carrier-free self-assembled nanomedicines will bring important impetus to the modernization of traditional Chinese medicine and global health. According to the chemical structure characteristics, they can be divided into three categories: hydrolyzable tannins, condensed tannins and complex tannins [ 16 17 18 19 20 22 1 17 21 Flavonoids are an important class of plant secondary metabolites. The basic skeleton of flavonoids is composed of 2-phenylchromone, including two aromatic rings (A ring and B ring) through three carbon atoms of the connecting chain (C6–C3–C6) [ 23 15 24 26 27 25 26 In addition to polyphenols, pomegranate peel also contains a variety of other active ingredients: (1) Triterpenoids such as ursolic acid and oleanolic acid regulate inflammatory pathways through the synergistic effect of carboxyl and hydroxyl groups [ 4 28 3 15 1 21 2 5 29 21 30 32 21 33 36 Carrier-free self-assembly combination of active ingredients of pomegranate peel Ursolic acid Ursolic acid (UA), as a pentacyclic triterpenoid compound with self-assembly characteristics, has shown broad application potential in the field of nano-remediation due to its excellent biosafety and biological activity. Researchers have used a variety of methods to prepare a variety of ursolic acid-based nanoparticles for the treatment of different diseases. Near-spherical ursolic acid nanoparticles (UA NPs) with a diameter of about 150 nm were prepared by solvent exchange method. The self-assembly of UA NPs mainly depended on hydrophobic interaction and hydrogen bond interaction, and hydrophobic interaction may be the main driving force [ 37 38 13 39 40 41 Oleanolic acid Oleanolic acid (OA) is a naturally occurring pentacyclic triterpenoid that can self-assemble into hollow nanospheres (Wang et al., 2020b). Bag et al. self-assembled OA into biocompatible vesicles in 0.0025% (v/v) dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) aqueous solution, with a shape of 2.5–5.0 mm spherical aggregates [ 42 zeta 43 14 Gallic acid Gallic acid (GA) is a natural polyphenolic compound. The benzene ring, hydroxyl group and carboxyl group contained in the structure enable it to participate in self-assembly to form nanorods through non-covalent forces such as hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking [ 14 44 Chlorogenic acid Chlorogenic acid (CGA) is a natural polyphenolic compound, and berberine (BBR) is an isoquinoline alkaloid. The supramolecular Chinese medicine nanocomposite BBR/CGA was prepared by dialysis precipitation method, and its formation mainly depended on hydrogen bonding, π-π stacking, electrostatic adsorption and hydrophobic interaction. Specifically, there may be electrostatic interactions between the quaternary amine structure (positively charged N) of BBR and the carboxylic acid part of CGA, while π-π stacking and hydrogen bonding also play an important role in the self-assembly process. The results showed that tannic acid-berberine (TB) nanoparticles with uniform spherical structure were formed by self-assembly of berberine (BBR) and tannic acid at a molar ratio of 2:1. However, EA, GA and CA form a sandwich-like ellagic acid-gallic acid-catechin (EA-GA-CA) ternary self-assembly solubilization system through hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking. The system is irregularly spherical and the particle size is mainly in the range of 3–7 μm. Under the condition of alkaline aqueous solution, quercetin can undergo oxidative coupling reaction to form oligomers composed of five monomers. the active components such as ursolic acid, gallic acid, ellagic acid and quercetin in pomegranate peel achieved carrier-free self-assembly through non-covalent interactions such as intermolecular hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic interactions and π-π stacking, and confirmed that their self-assemblies not only retain the inherent pharmacological activities of each component, such as anti-inflammatory [ 93 43 37 42 14 40 94 Compared with traditional nanocarrier systems, carrier-free self-assembly systems have significant advantages in drug loading efficiency and biocompatibility. Traditional carriers usually have low drug loading rate and need to rely on exogenous materials, which have potential toxic and side effects [ 95 13 Although carrier-free self-assembly technology has shown significant advantages in improving the solubility, stability and bioavailability of pomegranate peel active ingredients, its development still faces multiple challenges. First of all, the formation of carrier-free nanoparticles lacks clear definition criteria, and a recognized criterion has not been established to determine whether it reaches the category of nanoparticles. The prediction and determination of self-assembly behavior lacks systematic models and theoretical guidance. The characterization methods are not uniform, and there is a lack of systematic standards to comprehensively evaluate its physical and chemical properties, structural characteristics and biological behavior, which limits the structural design and experimental repeatability. In addition, it is not clear whether a self-assembled structure with specific functions is formed during the traditional decoction or preparation process, and its energy change, force evolution and pharmacological activity still need to be further analyzed. The current research focuses on a single or two-component system, which is difficult to restore the multi-target effect of traditional Chinese medicine compound. The multi-molecular co-assembly mechanism and its in vivo behavior need to be explored. At the same time, pharmacokinetic studies are weak, and there is a lack of systematic evaluation of its absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion. In terms of biosafety, although the introduction of exogenous vectors is avoided, its long-term toxicity, immunogenicity and metabolic risk still need to be systematically evaluated. In the future, it is necessary to establish a standardized preparation process, introduce automated synthesis and high-throughput screening, and combine advanced imaging technology and multidimensional toxicological evaluation system to promote the clinical transformation of this technology.
